facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 203 of 1956 is an appeal by special leave from the orders dated January 25, 1955, of the Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 203 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the orders dated January 25, 1955, of the Madras High Court in C.M.P. No. 9335 of 1954 and S. R. No. 55247 of 1953. S. Krishnaswamy Iyengar, R. Ganapathy Iyer and G. Gopalakrishnan, for the appella

facts.text: Appellant filed Civil Suit No. 311 of 1951 on the Original Side of the Madras High Court claiming partition of joint family properties and accounts.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant bad filed Civil Suit No. 311 of 1951 on the Original Side of the Madras High Court. In this suit be had claimed partition of the joint family, properties and an account in respect of the joint family assets managed by the respondent. The appellant is the son of Subbiah Chettiar.

facts.text: Appellant is the son of Subbiah Chettiar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the son of Subbiah Chettiar. His case was that Subbiah had been adopted by Lakshmi Achi in 1922. Lakshmi Achi was the widow of the undivided paternal uncle of the respondent.

facts.text: Subbiah Chettiar was adopted by Lakshmi Achi in 1922.

anchor.surface_text: His case was that Subbiah had been adopted by Lakshmi Achi in 1922. Lakshmi Achi was the widow of the undivided paternal uncle of the respondent. As a result of his adoption Subbiah became a companyarcener in his adoptive family and, as Subbiahs son, the appellant claimed to have a share in the joint family properties

facts.text: Lakshmi Achi was the widow of the undivided paternal uncle of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Lakshmi Achi was the widow of the undivided paternal uncle of the respondent. As a result of his adoption Subbiah became a companyarcener in his adoptive family and, as Subbiahs son, the appellant claimed to have a share in the joint family properties and in the assets of the joint family and that was the basis on which a claim for partition and accounts was made by the appellant in his suit.

facts.text: Subbiah filed a suit for partition of his share and obtained a decree in the trial court.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint it had been alleged that Subbiah had filed a suit for partition of his share and had obtained a decree in the trial companyrt. The respondent had taken an appeal against the said decree in the High Court.

facts.text: Respondent took an appeal against Subbiah's partition decree in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had taken an appeal against the said decree in the High Court. Pending the appeal the dispute was settled amicably between the parties and in companysideration of payment of a specified sum and delivery of possession of certain sites Subbiah agreed to release all his claims and those of his son, the present appellant, in respect of the properties then in suit.

facts.text: Pending the appeal, Subbiah and respondent settled amicably; Subbiah received payment and possession of sites and agreed to release claims including appellant's.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the appeal the dispute was settled amicably between the parties and in companysideration of payment of a specified sum and delivery of possession of certain sites Subbiah agreed to release all his claims and those of his son, the present appellant, in respect of the properties then in suit. According to the appellant, this companypromise transaction did number bind the appellant and so he claimed to recover his share ignoring the said transaction between his father and the respondent.

facts.text: Appellant claims the compromise transaction does not bind him.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant, this companypromise transaction did number bind the appellant and so he claimed to recover his share ignoring the said transaction between his father and the respondent. The plaint filed by the appellant valued the claim for accounts at Rs. 1,000 under s. 7 iv  f  of the Act and a companyrt fee of Rs. 112-7-0 was paid on the said amount on an ad valorem basis.

facts.text: Registry referred plaint fee issue to Master on October 18, 1951; Chamber Judge Krishnaswamy Naidu J. held fee under Art. 17-B correct.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Registry, on examining the plaint, was inclined to take the view that the plaint should have borne companyrt fee under s. 7 v  in respect of the claim for partition. ... This reference was decided by the Chamber Judge Krishnaswamy Naidu J. on October 18, 1951. The learned judge held that the appellant was number bound to set aside the prior companypromise decree between his father and the respondent and that the plaint was governed by Art. 17-B of Schedule 11.

facts.text: Respondent filed written statement contending compromise and release deed bound appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In due companyrse the respondent was served and he filed a written statement raising several companytentions against the appellants claim for partition and accounts. One of the points raised by the respondent was -that the companypromise and the release deed executed by the appellants father and the decree that was subsequently passed between the parties were fair and bona fide transactions

facts.text: Ramaswamy Gounder J. held compromise binding as preliminary issue and dismissed suit on September 22, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Ramaswamy Gounder J. who heard the suit tried the respondents companytention about the binding character of the companypromise decree as a preliminary issue. The learned judge held that there was a fair and bona fide settlement of the dispute by the appellants father acting as the manager of his branch and so the appellant was bound by the companypromise decree. In the result, the appellants suit was dismissed on September 22, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant filed memorandum of appeal on December 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decree the appellant presented his memorandum of appeal on December 1, 1953. This memorandum bore the same companyrt fees as the plaint.

facts.text: Division Bench on January 25, 1955 directed appellant to value partition relief under s. 7(iv)(b) at Rs. 15,00,000 for fees.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges who heard the reference did number think it necessary to companysider whether s. 12 of the Act was applicable to the present appeal. ... That is why the appellant was directed to mention his value for the relief of partition under the said section.

facts.text: Appellant valued partition relief at Rs. 50,000 and paid deficit fee Rs. 1,662-7-0 on May 7, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In companypliance with this order the appellant valued 1026 his relief to enforce his right to share in the joint family properties in suit at Rs. 50,000, paid the deficit companyrt fee Rs. 1,662-7-0 and re-presented his memorandum of appeal in companyrt on May 7, 1954.

facts.text: Appellant applied to amend plaint valuation on October 18, 1954; rejected by Division Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly the appellant made an application on October 18,1954. This application was opposed both by the respondent and the Assistant Government Pleader on behalf of the State. The learned judges who heard this application took the view that if the appellant had given the value in the first instance for purposes of jurisdiction he was precluded from giving a different value at a later stage.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal heard on November 28, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. November 28. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-This is a plaintiffs appeal by special leave against the order passed by a Division Bench of the Madras High Court on January 25, 1955, 1023 calling upon him to pay companyrt fees on the valuation of Rs. 15,00,000

facts.text: Krishnaswamy Naidu J. order on October 18, 1951 not final under s.5 as no appointment by Chief Justice shown.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges did number accept this companytention. They held that the record did number show that Krishnaswamy Naidu J. had been numberinated by the Chief Justice to. hear the reference under s. 5 either by a general or a special order and so numberfinality companyld be claimed for the said order under s. 5 of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Division Bench justified in exercising jurisdiction under s.12(2) of Court Fees Act.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the learned judges below were justified in assuming jurisdiction under sub-ss.  1  and  2  of s. 12.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside order and allowed appellant to value relief at Rs. 50,000 for court fees on plaint and appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly set aside the order under appeal and direct that the plaintiff should be allowed to state the amount of Rs. 50,000 at which he values the relief sought by him for the purpose of s. 7 iv  b  of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the order passed by the Chamber Judge on October 18, 1951, under s. 5 of the Court Fees Act is final.
Whether s. 12 of the Court Fees Act applies to appeals arising from suits on the Original Side of the Madras High Court.
Whether the Division Bench's decision that s. 7(iv)(b) applies to the claim for partition is final under s. 5 of the Court Fees Act.
Whether the appellant must pay court fees on the plaint and memorandum of appeal based on the jurisdictional valuation of Rs. 15,00,000 or on the valuation under s. 7(iv)(b).
Whether the value for court fees under s. 7(iv) determines the value for jurisdiction under s. 8 of the Suits Valuation Act.

anchor.surface_text: What would be the value for the purpose of jurisdiction in such suits is another question which often arises for decision. This question has to be decided by reading s. 7 of the Act along with s. 8 of the Suits Valuation Act.

holdings.text: The order passed by the Chamber Judge Krishnaswamy Naidu J. on October 18, 1951 under s.5 of the Court Fees Act is not final.

anchor.surface_text: That is why we must hold that the learned judges of the Division Bench were right in refusing to attach finality to the order passed by Krishnaswamy Naidu J.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No record shows nomination by Chief Justice generally or specially under s.5; practice assumption insufficient.

holdings.text: Section 12 of the Court Fees Act applies to appeals arising from suits on the Original Side of the Madras High Court via High Court Fees Rules.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the learned judges below were justified in assuming jurisdiction under sub-ss. 1 and 2 of s. 12.

holdings.reasoning_summary: O.II r.1 and O.XI r.1 extend Act provisions including s.12 'in every other respect' to Original Side suits and appeals; logical to allow review of deficient fees analogous to refunds under ss.13-15.

holdings.text: The Division Bench's decision that s.7(iv)(b) applies to the partition claim is final under s.5 of the Court Fees Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Properly referred by Master under s.5 and decided by Division Bench constituted by Chief Justice; merits not reopened.

holdings.text: The Division Bench erred in directing payment of court fees on plaint and appeal based on jurisdictional valuation of Rs.15,00,000 instead of Rs.50,000 under s.7(iv)(b).
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.7(iv)(b) allows plaintiff to value relief for fees; prior Division Bench order final on applicability; amendment should be allowed to conform.

holdings.text: The value stated by plaintiff under s.7(iv)(b) for court fees determines the value for jurisdiction under s.8 of the Suits Valuation Act.

anchor.surface_text: What would be the value for the purpose of jurisdiction in such suits is another question which often arises for decision. This question has to be decided by reading s. 7 of the Act along with s. 8 of the Suits Valuation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.8 SVA makes jurisdiction value same as court fee value under s.7(iv); fee valuation primary as plaintiff options in partition suits; not vice versa; liberty to amend.

holdings.text: Set aside Division Bench order of January 25, 1955 and allow plaintiff to value partition relief at Rs.50,000 for court fees on plaint and appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly set aside the order under appeal and direct that the plaintiff should be allowed to state the amount of Rs. 50,000 at which he values the relief sought by him for the purpose of s. 7 iv b of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from holdings on s.7(iv)(b), s.5 finality, s.12 jurisdiction, and s.8 SVA; plaintiff exercised option post-Division Bench direction.

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection we may point out that this is the view taken by the Full Bench decision of the Lahore High Court in Karam Ilahi v. Muhammad Bashir  1 . As we have already indicated s. 8 of the Suits Valuation Act postulates that the plaintiff should first value his claim for the purpose of companyrt fee and it provides for the determination of the value for jurisdiction on the basis of such claim. In our opinion, therefore, the learned judges

Shri Krishnaswamy Ayyangar has orally requested us to give him liberty to make the appropriate amendment in his plaint and we have granted his request. anchor.surface_text: That is why we must hold that the learned judges of the Division Bench were right in refusing to attach finality to the order passed by Krishnaswamy Naidu J.

We must accordingly set aside the order under appeal and direct that the plaintiff should be allowed to state the amount of Rs. 50,000 at which he values the relief sought by him for the purpose of s. 7 iv b of the Act. Shri Krishnaswamy Ayyangar has orally requested us to give him liberty to make the appropriate amendment in his plaint and we have granted his request. In the result the appeal would be allowed and the appellant directed to pay additional companyrt fees on his plaint on the basis of the valuation of Rs. 50,000 within two mo

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the learned judges below were justified in assuming jurisdiction under sub-ss. 1 and 2 of s. 12.

Shri Krishnaswamy Ayyangar has orally requested us to give him liberty to make the appropriate amendment in his plaint and we have granted his request.
